sharp.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: having a very thin edge or point that can cut things easily
sharp.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Make sure you use a good sharp knife.
Its teeth are razor sharp (=very sharp).
sharp.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: a sharp turn or bend changes direction suddenly
sharp.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: We came to a sharp bend in the road.
Take a sharp left after the church.
sharp.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: a sharp increase, rise, fall etc happens suddenly and is great in amount
sharp.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: sharp differences are very big and very noticeable
sharp.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: There is a sharp distinction between domestic and international politics.
His honesty is in sharp contrast to (=very different from) some other politicians.
sharp.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: a sharp pain or feeling is sudden and severe
sharp.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: I felt a sharp pain in my back.
I was left with a sharp sense of disappointment.
sharp.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: speaking in a way that shows you disapprove of something or are annoyed
sharp.translation[0].definitions[5].note: somebody has a sharp tongue (=they speak in a very disapproving way which often upsets people)
sharp.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: The boss can be very sharp with people when she’s busy.
sharp.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: able to think and understand things very quickly, and not easily deceived
sharp.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: a journalist with an extremely sharp mind
sharp.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: having a very thin point that can draw an exact line
sharp.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: Make sure your pencils are sharp before we begin the test.
sharp.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: a sharp sound or cry is loud, short, and sudden
sharp.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: Add mustard to give the dressing a sharper taste.
sharp.translation[0].definitions[10].exa: Tod looked really sharp in his tux.
sharp.translation[0].definitions[11].exa: Her mother had a sharp little nose.
sharp.translation[0].definitions[12].def: if an image or picture is sharp, you can see all the details very clearly
sharp.translation[0].definitions[12].exa: The outlines of the trees were sharp and clear.
sharp.translation[0].definitions[13].def: able to see and notice details very well
sharp.translation[0].definitions[13].not: a sharp eye for detail (=the ability to notice and deal with details)
sharp.translation[0].definitions[14].def: a musical note that is sharp has been raised by one semitone from the note F, D, C etc
sharp.translation[0].definitions[15].def: if music or singing is sharp, it is played or sung at a slightly higher pitch than it should be
sharp.translation[0].note_box[0].section: having a very thin edge or point that can cut things easily
The dog’s teeth were very sharp.
Be careful. That knife’s very sharp.
Puppies mean to be playful, but their sharp teeth can give you a nasty bite.
having an irregular edge with a lot of sharp points
The floor was covered with jagged pieces of glass.
having a lot of thin sharp points
The hedgehog uses its spiky fur for protection.
Some corals are quite smooth, others are sharp and spiky.
covered in a lot of small sharp points – used mainly about plants
a serrated edge on a saw or knife has a lot of sharp points on it
It’s best to use a knife with a serrated edge.
not sharp – used about tools, weapons, or pencils
All the kitchen knives were blunt.
The woman had been attacked with a blunt instrument.
sharp.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: played or sung at a slightly higher pitch than is correct
sharp.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: a musical note that has been raised one semitone above the note written
sharp.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: the sign (#) in a line of written music, used to show that a musical note should be raised
sharp.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: a brand (=type) of electronic products, that includes televisions, stereo systems, and DVD players, made by the Japanese company Sharp
sharp.translation[4].definitions[0].defi: a sharp increase, fall etc is very sudden and very big
sharp.translation[4].definitions[0].exam: a sharp rise in interest rates
Unemployment generally brings a sharp fall in income.
The group reported a sharp decline in full-year profits.
